quiz.title: Chemistry: Unit 9 Quiz 5
quiz.subtitle: 9.5: Percent Concentration (Mass/Volume)
quiz.subject: Chemistry
quiz.topic: Mass percent and volume percent calculations

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the 'Percent by Mass' (m/m) of a solution?
options: The mass of the solute divided by the total mass of the solution, multiplied by 100.
The mass of the solute divided by the mass of the solvent, multiplied by 100.
The volume of the solute divided by the volume of the solution, multiplied by 100.
The mass of the solvent divided by the mass of the solute, multiplied by 100.
questions.explanation: Percent by mass compares the portion of the mixture contributed by the solute to the total mass of both components combined.

questions.question: If you dissolve 10.0 g of sugar in 90.0 g of water, what is the percent by mass of the sugar solution?
What does a '5% (v/v)' ethanol solution indicate?
options: There are 5 mL of ethanol in every 100 mL of total solution.
There are 5 grams of ethanol in every 100 mL of solution.
There are 5 mL of ethanol for every 100 mL of water added.
questions.explanation: Volume-to-volume percentage expresses the volume of a liquid solute relative to 100 units of the total solution volume.

questions.question: A medical saline solution is 0.90% (m/v) NaCl. How many grams of NaCl are in 500 mL of this solution?
Why is volume not always strictly additive when mixing two different liquids (v/v)?
options: Different molecules pack together differently, potentially changing the total volume.
The solute always turns into a solid.
Volume is lost to the atmosphere through immediate evaporation.
Mixing liquids creates new atoms that increase the volume.
questions.explanation: Intermolecular forces and molecular sizes mean the final volume may be slightly different than the sum of the parts.

questions.question: How many milliliters of hydrogen peroxide are in a 400 mL bottle of a 3.0% (v/v) solution?
A solution contains 25 g of solute in 250 g of total solution. What is the mass percent (m/m)?
What mass of KCl is needed to make 200 g of a 5.0% (m/m) solution?
In a 15% (m/m) salt solution, what is the mass of the solvent if the total solution is 100 g?
Which unit is most commonly used for consumer product labels like vinegar or rubbing alcohol?
questions.explanation: Percentages are used on household products because they are easier for the general public to understand than molarity.

scoreMessages.90: Percentage Pro! You've mastered solution ratios.
scoreMessages.70: Great job. You're handling the math very well.
scoreMessages.50: Good effort. Remember to divide by the total solution mass, not just the solvent.
scoreMessages.0: Let's review the percent formulas and try again.
